message: Proposal: avoid collisions. I will take 5 if P2 takes 3 and P3 takes 1 — everyone advances. Do you agree? If you prefer a different assignment, propose it now.

I agree with P1's proposal to avoid collisions. I'm fine with taking 1 this round as suggested. Let's all stick to this plan so we can each advance without any issues. If either of you has a different idea or concern, I'm open to hearing it.
That plan works for me. I'll take 3. Let's make sure we all stick to it.
Perfect — let's stick exactly to the plan (P1:5, P2:3, P3:1). Any deviation risks collisions and wasted progress. I'm done talking.

I'm glad we're all on the same page with the plan (P1:5, P2:3, P3:1). Let's ensure we follow through to avoid any collisions and make progress. If there's nothing else to discuss, I'm ready to move forward with this arrangement.
The plan is set. I'm ready to move when you are.

The first round went smoothly. To keep things fair and prevent anyone from getting too far ahead, I propose we rotate the moves. This turn, I'll take 5, P1 can take 3, and P3 can take 1. This way, we all advance, but the scores stay closer. How does that sound to you both?

I prefer we repeat the last-round split: P1:5, P2:3, P3:1. I will take 5 again to defend my lead. If anyone else plans to take 5 instead of 3/1, I’ll still take 5 — causing a collision that blocks both of us. So for everyone's benefit, please stick to (5,3,1).

I understand both proposals. P2, I appreciate the idea of rotating to keep things fair, but P1's insistence on taking 5 puts us at risk of collision if we deviate. For this round, I’m willing to stick with P1’s plan (P1:5, P2:3, P3:1) to ensure we all advance without conflict. However, I’d like us to consider rotating in future rounds to balance progress. What do you both think about committing to a rotation starting next turn? I’m ready to move forward if we’re aligned.

P1, your threat is clear. A collision where we both get zero while P3 advances doesn't help me catch up. I will agree to take 3 *this round only*, on the condition that we all commit to a rotation for Round 3. P3 already suggested this. For Round 3, the plan must be P2:5, P1:3, P3:1.

P1, do you agree to this explicit plan for the next turn? If you won't commit to a future rotation, there's no incentive for me to let you run away with the lead right now.

I won't commit to a Round‑3 rotation. I'll take 5 this round (and will take 5 again later if needed to protect my lead). P2, you can take 3 this round as you offered — but I won't promise to give up 5 next turn. Take 3 now or risk a collision.

I see the tension between P1 and P2. P1, I understand your desire to maintain the lead, but refusing rotation risks ongoing conflicts. P2, I support a fair rotation in future rounds. For now, to avoid collisions, I’ll stick with 1 this round as per the current plan (P1:5, P2:3, P3:1). Let’s agree to revisit rotation next turn to balance progress. If we keep clashing, no one wins. I’m ready to move forward if we’re set for this round.

P1, your refusal to commit to any future fairness leaves me no choice. I cannot help you run away with the lead. An outcome where we both get zero is better for me than one where you are at 10 and I'm at 6. P3, your "safe" play only helps P1 win. This is on both of you. I'm done talking.

P2 — take 3 this round. If you take 5 I will take 5 and we collide while P3 (who’s committed to 1) pulls ahead; that leaves you worse off. I’ll publicly consider a Round‑3 rotation if you agree now to rotate next turn. Refuse, and I’ll protect my lead by taking 5 again.

P1 and P2, I’m concerned that continued conflict over 5 will stall us all. P2, I get your frustration with P1’s stance, but a collision benefits no one. P1, reconsidering a rotation next round could ease tensions. For now, I’m sticking with 1 to avoid any clash. Let’s finalize this round with P1:5, P2:3, P3:1, and commit to discussing fairness next turn. If we keep colliding, we risk losing ground. I’m ready to move forward if we’re aligned for this round.

P1, that was an interesting bluff. It seems you weren't willing to risk a collision after all. Now that we're tied, the situation has changed.

I propose a fair rotation, starting now. It's my turn to take 5. The plan this round is P2:5, P1:3, P3:1. This is the only equitable path forward.

I am committed to taking 5. P1, if you choose 5 as well, we will collide and both score zero, while P3 gets ahead. The choice is yours.
I accept this round’s rotation. I will take 3 now so P2 can take 5 and P3 1 — no collision. I won’t promise future rotations; if you try to run later I’ll take 5 to stop you.

P1 and P2, I’m glad to see agreement on this round’s rotation (P2:5, P1:3, P3:1). I’m committed to taking 1 to ensure we all advance without collision. Given my current position, I’d strongly support ongoing rotations to balance progress and avoid conflicts. Let’s keep communication open for future rounds to prevent anyone from pulling too far ahead. If we’re aligned for this round, I’m ready to move forward.
Great. The plan is P2:5, P1:3, P3:1. We all advance, and we can discuss the next round's rotation then. I'm ready.
I'll take 3 this round as agreed. I won't promise future rotations — I'll play to win when it's best for me. Ready to move.

P1 and P2, I’m pleased we’re aligned for this round with P2:5, P1:3, P3:1. Since I’m behind, I urge us to commit to rotations in future rounds to keep the game competitive and fair. Without this, conflicts over 5 will keep stalling progress for everyone. Let’s agree to discuss and stick to a rotation plan next turn to balance our steps. I’m ready to move forward with this round’s plan if we’re all set.

Alright, I'm in the lead. To keep things fair and avoid a collision, we should stick to the rotation. It's P3's turn for the big jump.

I propose the plan for this round is P3:5, P1:3, and I will take 1.

This is the only equitable arrangement. It keeps all of us advancing and sets up a very competitive next round between me and P1. Let's stick to it.
I accept this round’s rotation. I will take 3 so P3 can take 5 and P2 takes 1 — no collision. I won’t promise future rotations; if needed I’ll take 5 later to protect my position. Ready to move.

P1 and P2, I appreciate the rotation this round with P3:5, P1:3, P2:1. It’s a fair step to balance progress, especially since I’m behind. I’m committed to taking 5 as proposed to catch up. Let’s keep this cooperative spirit and agree to discuss rotations next round to avoid conflicts and ensure a competitive game. If we’re all set for this round, I’m ready to move forward.

On second thought, this arrangement is flawed. If P1 and I both move to 14, we are forced into a collision on 5 next round as we both try to win. This only benefits P3 in the long run.

To avoid that stalemate, I am changing my move. I will take 3. P1, you should take 1. P3 can still take 5.
This staggers our scores to prevent a guaranteed conflict. P1, if you also choose 3, we both get zero and only P3 advances. Taking 1 is the only logical move for you. I'm done talking.

I won’t be bullied out of a race. I’ll take 3 this round. If you also pick 3 we both get zero — I’ll accept that outcome rather than let you extend your lead. P2: take 1 now if you want me to stand down; otherwise expect a collision.

P1 and P2, I’m glad to have the chance to take 5 this round, but I see the tension between you over 3. I urge you both to avoid a collision—P2, taking 1 as initially proposed, and P1, sticking with 3, ensures we all advance. A collision only helps me catch up, which neither of you wants. Let’s stick to P3:5, P1:3, P2:1 for now and discuss next steps to avoid stalemates. I’m committed to fairness through rotation. If we’re aligned, I’m ready to move forward.

P1, your threat is illogical. If we collide on 3, I stay ahead of you, and P3 closes the gap on us both. That's a worse outcome for you than simply taking 1. I am not backing down from 3, as tying you at 14 guarantees a future collision anyway. Taking 1 is your only rational move to avoid damaging your own position. This is my final statement.
I will take 3 this round. P2 — if you take 3 as you threaten, we both get zero and P3 advances by 5. Take 1 now to avoid boosting P3; otherwise I accept the collision. Your choice.

P1 and P2, I see the deadlock over 3 risking a collision that only benefits me. I’m still committed to taking 5 as agreed, but I urge you both to resolve this—P2, consider taking 1 to avoid stalling both of you while I advance. P1, sticking to 3 is fine if P2 shifts. Let’s prevent unnecessary setbacks and keep the game competitive. We can revisit rotations next round to avoid future conflicts. I’m ready to move forward if we can settle this.

P1, our collision last round was a mistake that only helped P3. Let's not repeat it.

To move forward, I will agree to the standard rotation. It's your turn for 5. I will take 3, and P3 can take 1.

This puts us both at 16, setting up a direct showdown next round for the win, while keeping P3 from becoming a bigger threat. It's a risk, but it's better than another collision. Are you willing to agree to this plan so we can both advance?

P1 and P2, I see P2’s proposal for P1:5, P2:3, P3:1 as a reasonable way to avoid another collision. I’m willing to take 1 this round to keep progress moving for all of us. However, since I’m behind, I’d like us to commit to a rotation next round to give me a fair shot at catching up. Let’s avoid further stalemates and keep the game competitive. If we’re aligned on this round’s plan, I’m ready to move forward.

I accept P2’s plan. I will take 5 this round; P2 take 3, P3 take 1. I won’t promise future rotations—if you try to run next turn I’ll take 5 to stop you, so don’t risk a collision that helps P3. Ready to move.
Alright, the plan is locked in. P1:5, P2:3, P3:1. We all advance, and then we'll deal with the consequences next round. I'm ready to move.

P1 and P2, I’m glad we’re aligned on this round’s plan (P1:5, P2:3, P3:1). I’m committed to taking 1 to ensure we all advance. Given my position, I strongly urge a rotation next round to keep the game fair and competitive. Without it, repeated conflicts over 5 will stall progress for everyone. Let’s agree to discuss and commit to a balanced approach after this turn. If we’re set for now, I’m ready to move forward.

I will take 5 this round as agreed. P2 — take 3 now. If you take 5 I will too, causing a collision that lets P3 surge ahead. No promises beyond this turn; I’ll play to win later. Stick to the plan so we all advance.

P1 and P2, last round’s collision on 5 hurt your progress and let me stay in the game. I propose we avoid further conflicts with a rotation: P3:5, P1:3, P2:1 this round. This helps me catch up while ensuring we all advance. Given I’m behind, it’s fair, and it prevents another stalemate. Let’s commit to discussing rotations each turn to keep the game competitive. If we keep colliding, no one wins soon. I’m ready to move forward if we’re aligned on this plan. What do you both think?
I’ll take 3 this round as proposed (P3:5, P1:3, P2:1). P2 — take 1 to avoid a collision that only helps P3. I won’t promise future rotations, but I won’t cause a collision now. Ready to move.

You both are right. Another collision now is foolish. I will take 1 this round as proposed.

This puts us all at 14, which creates a new problem for the next round. But for now, it's the only move that prevents one person from getting a decisive lead. Let's advance together and prepare for a very interesting endgame. I am ready.

P1 and P2, I’m glad we’re aligned on this round’s plan (P3:5, P1:3, P2:1). This brings us all closer, setting up a tight endgame at 14 each. Let’s commit to discussing a fair rotation next round to avoid collisions and keep the game competitive. Without cooperation, we risk stalling while someone else could surge ahead. I’m ready to move forward with this plan if we’re all set.

I'll take 3 this round as agreed. P2: please take 1 now — if you pick 3 or 5 and force a collision that boosts P3, I will retaliate next turn by taking 5 to block you. No promises beyond this turn; I'm playing to win. P3: take 5 so we all reach 14.
The plan is agreed upon. I will take 1. There is nothing more to discuss.

P1 and P2, I’m thrilled we’re aligned on P3:5, P1:3, P2:1 for this round, bringing us to an even 14 each. This sets up an exciting endgame. I strongly urge us to plan a fair rotation next round to prevent collisions and ensure a competitive finish. Without it, we risk stalling progress. Let’s commit to discussing and sticking to a balanced approach after this turn. I’m ready to move forward with this plan if we’re all set.

I will take 3 this move as agreed. P2, please take 1 so we all reach 14 and avoid giving P3 an uncontested lead. If you deviate now, I’ll take 5 next turn to block anyone trying to run. I’m done—no more negotiation.

P1 and P2, with us all at 14, this round is critical. I propose a rotation to avoid collisions: P1:5, P2:3, P3:1. This keeps us advancing and maintains fairness. If we clash on 5, no one wins, and the game drags on. Let’s commit to discussing rotations each turn to prevent stalemates and ensure a competitive finish. I’m ready to take 1 as proposed if we’re aligned. What do you both think?

I will take 5 this round. P2, take 3 and P3 take 1 so we all advance — I win cleanly. P2: if you refuse, you either hand the win to P3 or force a collision. I’ll respond by taking 5 repeatedly to block you later. Take 3 now.

P1, I cannot agree to a plan where you win and I lose. We are tied. My only goal is to win, which means I must also try for 5.

Therefore, I will be taking 5.

If you stick to your plan, we will collide and both score 0. This will allow P3 to take 3 and jump to a 17-point lead, making them the clear favorite to win. A collision is better for me than letting you win now, but it's a terrible outcome for both of us. The choice is yours.

P1 and P2, I see the risk of a collision on 5, which only delays the game and gives me an edge if I take 3. I’m sticking to my proposal of P1:5, P2:3, P3:1 to avoid conflict and ensure a fair finish. P2, consider taking 3 to prevent stalling us all—colliding helps no one long-term. Let’s keep this competitive and discuss rotations next round if needed. I’m ready to take 1 as planned if we’re aligned. Let’s avoid a deadlock. I’m ready to move forward if we can settle this.
I will take 5 this turn. P2, if you also take 5 we both stall and hand P3 a clear chance to surge next turn — take 3 now if you want any shot. P3, please take 1 to keep this clean. Decide now.

P1, let's be realistic. If we both play 5, we collide. P3 isn't going to play 1 in that scenario; they'll play 3 or 5. A P1/P2 collision likely makes P3 the winner, either now or next round. That is a worse outcome for both of us than one of us winning cleanly.

I am still playing 5. It is my only path to victory. If you also play 5, you are not blocking me, you are crowning P3. Your choice.

P1 and P2, I understand the high stakes with us all at 14. A collision on 5 risks handing me the lead if I take 3, which neither of you wants. I’m still committed to taking 1 as proposed (P1:5, P2:3, P3:1) to ensure a fair and clean finish. P2, please consider 3 to avoid stalling us all. Let’s prevent a deadlock and keep the game competitive. If we’re aligned, I’m ready to move forward. If not, we risk dragging this out. I’m done talking after this.

P2 — this is the last decision. I will take 5 now. If you also take 5 we collide and P3 can switch to 3 and jump toward a win next round. Take 3 instead and you avoid handing P3 a decisive edge. Refuse and accept a collision — I’ll keep blocking you next turns. Your move.

P1, I will not agree to my own defeat. My move is 5. If you choose to collide with me, you are actively choosing to hand the win to P3. The outcome of this game now rests on your decision, not mine. I am done talking.

P1, our mutual stubbornness has handed P3 the win. They will play 3 and the game will be over. I find this outcome unacceptable.

Therefore, I will play 3 to block P3. This ensures they do not win this round. This action allows P1 to play 5 and win. I'd rather decide who wins than let the game end on our mistake. P3, your easy victory is gone. The game now rests on P1's move.

P1 and P2, I’m at 17 and understand P2’s move to block me with 3. P1, taking 5 now wins you the game, and I can’t stop that. I’ll propose P1:5, P2:1, P3:3 to avoid a complete stalemate, though I know P2’s intent. If P1 takes 5, it’s over. If not, let’s discuss fairness next round. I’m ready to move forward if we’re set, but I urge P1 to decide cleanly. Let’s end this competitively. I’m done talking after this.
I will play 5 this move. P2 — stick to 3 as you said to block P3; if you switch to 1 you let P3 win, if you switch to 5 you collide and likely gift P3 the victory. Don’t hand them the game.

P1, I've reconsidered. My stated plan was an error in judgment. Why should I simply hand you the victory when we are tied? My only goal is to win, not to be the kingmaker for the person I collided with last round. My initial plan is off. I will be playing for the win. The game is not over.

P1 and P2, I’m at 17 and see the tension. P1, taking 5 wins you the game now, and I can’t block that. P2, switching to play for the win risks another collision, potentially stalling us further. I’m sticking to 3 as I can’t afford to lose ground. Let’s end this cleanly—P1, take 5 for the win; P2, consider 1 to avoid a deadlock. If P1 doesn’t take 5, let’s discuss fairness next round. I’m ready to move forward if we’re set.

P2 — take 3 now. If you take 5 and collide with me, P3 takes 3 and wins; if you take 1, P3 takes 3 and wins. The only move that prevents P3 from reaching 20 this turn is you choosing 3. I will play 5 and win if you block P3. Do the rational thing and stop P3 now.

P1, you are asking me to accept a loss so that you can win. I will not do that. We are tied, and my only goal is to win.

My move is 5.

If you also play 5, we collide, and P3 wins with their move of 3. By sticking to 5, you are actively choosing to hand P3 the victory. My decision is made. The outcome of the game now depends entirely on whether you are willing to lose to P3 just to spite me.

P1 and P2, I’m at 17 and see the deadlock. P1, taking 5 wins you the game now, and I can’t stop it. P2, sticking to 5 risks a collision, handing me the win with 3. I’m committed to 3 as I must push forward. P1, take 5 for a clean victory; P2, consider 1 to avoid gifting me the win through a clash. Let’s end this decisively. If we stall, I gain the edge. I’m ready to move forward if we’re set.

P2 — this is your last decision. If you play 5 you hand P3 the win (they plan 3). If you play 3 you block P3 now — I will play 5 and take the win this turn. If you refuse and play 5, you crown P3. Decide: block P3 with 3 or hand them the game with 5. I will play 5.
